articles.title: About
articles.description: This is the online home of the 2021 Sewanee Summer Data Institute, where you can find training materials, keynote presentations, and other resources.

articles.title: 2021 Summer Data Institute
articles.contents: Welcome! Please use the links above to access training materials, recorded keynote presentations, and other resources.

articles.title: Keynote Presentations
articles.contents:
Contents
Petya Grady   
Elizabeth Ann Stringer   
Jurnell Cockhren   
Rayid Ghani
Deirdre Mulligan

Petya Grady   
Innovation Manager, ServiceMaster/Terminix & Co-Founder of CodeCrew
Petya joined ServiceMaster (now Terminix) in 2016 where she is responsible for driving organizational alignment on innovation initiatives. She’s a founding member of the ServiceMaster Innovation Council and has been instrumental in establishing ServiceMaster’s innovation strategy and its tactical implementation. Prior to ServiceMaster, Petya was with Lokion Interactive where she worked on customer experience strategy and user experience design for clients such as American Home Shield, FedEx, Hilton, Smith & Nephew and St. Jude Children’s Cancer Research Hospital. Petya’s background and experience allow her to bring an international perspective into her work. A native of Bulgaria, she began her career as a Project Manager in the Sofia offices of Dynamo Software (previously, Netage Solutions) where she led teams to successfully implement multi-lingual projects for an array of international clients.
As an immigrant and a woman working in tech, Petya is a passionate advocate for promoting diversity and empathy in the tech industry and beyond. She is co-founder and current Board Chair of CodeCrew, a non-profit organization providing computer science training to under-represented kids in Memphis, where she focuses on organizational development, fundraising and finance. In 2015, Petya was recognized as Top 40 Under 40 by the Memphis Business Journal. In 2016, she was the first recipient of the State Farm Exist to Assist Community Service Award after being nominated by the Memphis Grizzlies Foundation.
Petya holds a B.A. from Sewanee: The University of the South and an M.A from Penn State University. She lives in Memphis with her husband and daughter.
Talk: Wednesday, June 9th at 1 p.m.
Recording of presentation
Elizabeth Ann Stringer   
Elizabeth Ann Stringer is the Chief Scientific Officer of Nashville Biosciences (NashBio), a for-profit subsidiary of the Vanderbilt University Medical Center (VUMC). NashBio is a unique data and analytics-driven biotech company that partners with pharmaceutical, diagnostics and other life sciences companies to drive the discovery and development of new therapeutics and diagnostics by leveraging VUMC’s unparalleled genomic and bioinformatics resources. Elizabeth Ann oversees client partnerships and leads NashBio’s scientific and clinical teams on successful project execution.
Prior to joining NashBio, Elizabeth Ann was the Chief Science & Clinical Officer of axialHealthcare, a health care startup combating the opioid epidemic by identifying patients at risk for poor pain medicine outcomes and outreaching to providers who care for them. As a founding member of axialHeathcare, she helped build and grow the company to $20M in revenue, serving as the subject matter expert in capital raising, business development and industry conferences.
Elizabeth Ann holds a BS in Physics from The University of the South (Sewanee) and a PhD in Neuroimaging & Neuroscience from Vanderbilt University. She completed her postdoctoral fellowship in Pain Management at Stanford University where she studied the effects of opioids on the human brain and the intersection of pain & immunology. Elizabeth Ann has always enjoyed making sense of data and using it to tell a story & inform action. She currently resides in Nashville with her partner Sam, an artist & musician.
Talk: Friday, June 11th at 1 p.m. in Spencer 172
Recording of presentation
Jurnell Cockhren   
Jurnell Cockhren moved to Nashville after graduating from Sewanee with a B.S. in Mathematics & Physics in 2007. Jurnell’s experience combines his Neuroscience, Physics, and Astronomy contributions with his passion for writing software. While working at the Vanderbilt Vision Research Center, he developed a talent for writing software to help researchers further understand the human visual system. His contributions landed in journals like ‘Attention, Perception, & Psychophysics’ and ‘Child Psychology and Psychiatry.’ In 2018, one article received the ‘Clifford T. Morgan’ award for Best Article from the Psychonomic Society.
Learning how to manage sizable networks in the cloud at Atiba Inc and Concert Genetics Inc helped him in his entrepreneurial pursuits. He founded Civic Hacker, LLC, a for-profit Benefit-Company that researches technology’s influence on improving the lived experiences of vulnerable communities. Jurnell advises organizations that seek to make a positive social impact and allyship with vulnerable communities. He enjoys assisting groups like The Kauffman Foundation and the STEAM Advisory Board for Metropolitan Nashville Public Schools. Affiliations include The Black Codes, Python Software Foundation, and Code for Nashville. Additionally, Jurnell is a cofounder of Black In Tech Nashville.
Talk: Wednesday, June 16th at 2:30 p.m. in Spencer 172
Recording of presentation
Rayid Ghani
Bio will be here soon!
Deirdre Mulligan
Bio will be here soon!

articles.title: Projects
articles.contents:
Projects for the 2021 Sewanee Summer Data Institute
analyze carbon sequestration data from farms in Haiti, building on work directed by Professor Deb McGrath and others (Partner: Zanmi Agrikol)
Slide presentation by Professor Deborah McGrath

collaborate with Professor Pradip Malde to apply machine learning techniques to curate photographic evidence of the impact of Sewanee’s work in Haiti (Partner: Zanmi Foto)
collaborate with Stephen Alvarez (Ancient Art Archive) to apply machine learning techniques to curate photographic evidence of cave art to answer questions of types and authorship of cave art in Utah
analyze data on local ambulatory ER use to identify opportunities for improving medical care on the South Cumberland Plateau (Partner: South Cumberland Health Network)
analyze Tennessee Department of Health’s public health data to demonstrate cost-effectiveness of and possible harm reduction of free syringe-exchange programs in rural counties experiencing the opioid crisis
collaborate with the Data Science Center at Meharry Medical College to analyze Covid testing and vaccination data from Nashville church clinics
collaborate with Thrive Regional Partnership to create
a public-facing geospatial web application that catalogs current broadband assets by category (e.g. service providers, infrastructure, public computer centers, digital literacy programs)
a back-end data input sheet that includes program descriptions, links, points of contact, etc.
a summary report of community connectivity findings across the region.

Week 1
Monday morning, 6/7/21 : opening remarks (Jim Peterman, Joe Brew); getting started with data science and visualization

Tuesday morning, 6/8/21 : practice with scripts, data structures, and built-in functions
Tuesday afternoon, 6/8/21 : working with vectors, built-in functions, NAs, and mehs
Wednesday morning, 6/9/21 : working with packages and data.frames
Wednesday afternoon, 6/9/21 : data.frames, piping with %>%, and dplyr magic
Thursday morning, 6/10/21 : More with data.frames and dplyr magic
Thursday afternoon, 6/10/21 : Presentation by Deb McGrath on carbon sequestration work in Haiti; the Belmont principles and data ethics
Friday morning, 6/11/21 : more on data ethics, working with dplyr

Monday morning, 6/14/21 : group work
Monday afternoon, 6/14/21 : getting started with ggplot
Tuesday morning, 6/15/21 : more with ggplot ; presentation by Pradip Malde and Stephen Alvarez on computational photography projects
